name: Nicholas Spooner
content: Nicholas (Nick) Spooner Nicholas (Nick) Spooner nspooner [at] cornell [dot] edu I am an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at Cornell University, and a member of the Theory of Computing group. In summer 2025 I was a Simons-Berkeley Research Fellow in connection with the programme "Cryptography 10 Years Later". My work focuses on post-quantum proof systems. My interests include probabilistic proof systems and zero knowledge in general, post-quantum cryptography, quantum information, coding theory and computational complexity. I was an assistant professor at the University of Warwick until 2024, and a visiting assistant professor at NYU for the 2023-24 academic year. Before that, I was a postdoc at Boston University, hosted by Ran Canetti. I received my PhD from UC Berkeley, where I was advised by Alessandro Chiesa. I hold a master's degree in theoretical computer science from ETH Zürich, Switzerland, and a bachelor's degree in computer science from the University of Cambridge. Teaching Fall 2025: CS 6832: Quantum Cryptography at Cornell. Spring 2025: CS 4813: Quantum Computing at Cornell. Fall 2024: CS 6814: Probabilistic Proofs at Cornell. Spring 2024: CSCI-UA.0480-​074 Quantum Computing at NYU. Fall 2023: CSCI-GA.3033-​103 Quantum Computing at NYU. Spring 2022, Spring 2023: CS419/939 Quantum Computing at Warwick.
